newsitem.title: USA: Oil price rally fades after surge on Iraq events.
newsitem.headline: Oil price rally fades after surge on Iraq events.

text.p: Oil prices in New York surged 5 percent Tuesday after the latest confrontation between the United States and Iraq.
Crude oil for October delivery closed up $1.15 at $23.40 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange after rising as high as $24.25 in early trading.

The initial surge came as the market returned from a long holiday weekend amid news of the U.S. missile strike against Iraq in response to Baghdad's incursion into protected Kurdish zones in the north of Iraq.

The Iraqi move caused United Nations Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali to suspend a deal that would have allowed Iraq to sell up to $2 billion of oil over six months to pay for badly needed food and medicines.
"I think the market has now reacted proportionately. People were saying it had gotten overbought," said one New York oil trader.
Although there had been numerous delays since negotiations began last March, the Iraq-U.N. oil deal had been expected to be implemented over the next several weeks.
The State Department and a U.S. envoy to the U.N. indicated it would be some time, perhaps several months, before the oil deal could be put back on track.
ING Derivatives analyst Tom Bentz said suspension of the deal will probably add about $1.50 to the price of a barrel of crude oil.
"I still think oil is going to $25 before the year is out. This just means it's going to get their sooner," said Bentz.
Benchmark West Texas oil prices hit a post-Gulf War high in April at $25.70 but slipped to below $20 during the summer.

U.S. envoy to the United Nations Edward Gnehm told Reuters that the length of any delay in implementing the oil-for-food deal depended on Saddam Hussein's next moves. He added that the terms of the deal would have to be re-examined in the wake of Baghdad's aggression, and said any resolution could take "months and months."

The deal would have allowed Iraq to sell about 700,000 barrels a day at a time when crude supplies are relatively tight. Moreover, historically low U.S. heating oil inventories are expected to require particulary high refinery runs.

"It changes the dynamic for the fourth quarter for oil," said Smith Barney analyst John Saucer. "Low refined products stocks promised higher refinery runs and now there won't be the Iraqi oil," he said.
Heating oil for October delivery closed up 1.95 cents a gallon at 65.07 cents while October gasoline rose 1.35 cents to 62.96 cents a gallon.

The fate of the oil-for-food deal was put into further uncertainty after the United States responded to Iraq's invasion in the Kurdish territory by firing 27 cruise missles against targets in southern Iraq.
Although market watchers said the possible fallout of the U.S. military strikes was still unknown, any possible ripple effect on U.S.-Arab relations would add volatility to prices.
"I think the market is in a new range. There is going to be a lot of volatlity from here," said Saucer.
